Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. In other words, every time the given number decreases by 1/2, the number of candies goes up by 6; every time the number decreases by 4/5, the number of candied goes up by 25; and so on. Here are your figures:<n><n>| Candy package | Amount (pieces) |<n>| ---| --- |<n>| Cups | <p id="math-000000200658"><strong>60/2</strong></p> |<n>| 5 cups | <p id='math-0001003000">400</p> |<n>| <p id='math_equation-0004005000'><span style="font-size:55px">400/2</span></p> |<n><n>### Rationales: The rationale will contain at least one of four categories of reasoning.<n>- Division<n>- Subtraction, addition, and multiplication<n>- Fractions and division or multiplication<n>- Combinations of any or all of the above<n><n>### Answers:<n>### InstructionAnswer the following multiple choice questions<n>In a certain city, there are 6 men and 8 women. Choices: A: reaches its max B: becomes negligible C: increases slowly D: decreases slowly E: never increases<n><n>### Answer: A. reaches its max is the correct answer. Choices:  A: at the zoo B: south carolina C: hen house D: louisiana E: arkansas<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is C<n><n>### Input :  What is the greatest common factor(GCF) of 75 and 863?<n><n>### Response :  The GCF(Greatest Common Factor) of 75 & 863 is 17<n>### Rationale:  We have to factorize the numbers in order to find their GCF, in order to factorize we divide with the largest factor till we get the prime or primes (prime numbers can be factored by 1 only so they do not divide), Lets say that the factors of 75 or 863 are 1,3,9,23 and 65 or 1,53 respectively. Then only factors of LCM(Least Common multiple)=Product of all the factors of both the numbers we are factoring, LCM= Product of all the factors =75 * 863 or 75 *5^2 * 2^3 =51875, if we divide 51875 with the LCM we get GCF.<n><n>### Input <n><n>Factorize (42^2-38^2)<n><n>### Rationale :<n><n>Factorize is similar to factoring a number means to divide in its common factors.<n><n><n>### Answer :<n><n>GCF =4. The greatest common factor of two positive integers a and b, written gcf(a,b), is the largest positive integer that divides both a and b with no remainder. That is,<n>   a = qb + r, where 0 ≤ r < b<n><n>and<n>   b = qa + r, where  r =0<n><n>It is not necessary to divide both integers.<n><n>\begin{code}<n>42^2 -38^2 =42*41 - 38*37 =256*4 - 136*3 =256  - 352 =792   15<n>       = (3*5^3 - 23*3)<n>       =<n>     4<n>\end{code}<n><n>### Input<n><n>> Which is bigger, 37 8 or -6080?<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>Answer: 608

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where would you get a contraceptive if you do not have one? Choices:  A: health center B: vagina C: emergency room D: drawer E: medicine cabinet<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choice D: drawer<n><n>Explanation: Drawer option was one of the answer choices to this question so <n>You should pick Drawer as your answer.<n><n>### Input<n>How many feet were there in 2,500 meters?<n><n>### Response<n><n>One thousand meters = <<One-thousand-meters=1,000>>1,000 feet<n>Therefore. One meter= <<One-meter=1>>1 foot<n>Therefore. 2,50 meters = <<2500-meters=2500>>2,500.<n>So one thousand divided by two, <<1000>>1000 feet<n>=<<500>>500 meters per foot<n><n>Feet are smaller since meters are much larger<n><n>#### 500<n>Answer: 500<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Sam found a giant hole in the plain.  What might this hole be called? Choices:  A: hill B: gorge C: sandplain D: cliff E: mountain<n><n>### Response:		 5/12<n>

Choices:  Choices:  A  : 13   B:18   C:20  D:12   E:9  F:14<n><n>How many days does he work? Choices:  B  : 10   C:7   D:6   E:1   F:5<n><n><n>### Response<n>Demonstration: 20 hours a week and 5 days a week.<n><n>Rational: <n>This week he worked 240 hours for work, in five days he worked 24hours a day (480 hours)<n>#### 240+480=720<n><n>#### 720/5=144<n><n>So the answer is 144<n><n>### Input<n>How long will the task take? Choices: A :3 years   B:2 years    C:1 year  D:18 months   E:6 months<n><n>How much material will the task will he use? Choices: A:30 m2   B:25 m2   C:17 m2    D:12m2   E:10m2<n><n><n>### Demostration:<n>It will take 4 years, and he will use 40 m2<n><n>Rational: If the material is used, 30 *5 40 18 *6<n><n>#### 18*6=108<n><n>#### 108 * 720  = 80320<n><n>####80320/18= 4475<n><n>#### 4475/12=372.5<n><n>####372.5*4=1490<n><n>So the answer will b 4 years and 6 months.<n><n>

Choices:  A: learning B: painful memories C: thinking D: awe inspiring E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## How many people have seen the artwork after you’ve analyzed?<n><n>- Rationale for choosing A<n>- Rationale for Choicing B<n>- Rationale for deciding C<n>- Rationale for D<n><n>- Rationale: for E<n><n>- Answer:<n><n>Answer: A<n>Input: An antelope lives in the mountains.  Each day it jumps over the same boulder a thousand times.  Then one day it does not jump over it. Why?<n>Rationales The antelope did not jump over the boulder because it already jumped over it 1000 times.<n>Answer: The antelope didnot jump over the boulders.<n><n>Answer: The lion doesnot eat an antelope.<n><n>Input: A cat has seven lives.  The cat is old and sick. Then it dies but gets resuscitated.  It lives four more days.  How many lives does it have after it has lived four days?<n>Rationales I know, there are 7 lives (or 8 lives) in the sentence, but they only count from zero.  We know the cat has 7 lives, but she has to lose one each time she dies.  Here is how it works:<n>  * The first time it dies, it's life nr. 7.<n>  * The cat does not die right away.  We assume that she survived the first time it died, which is why we're saying that 'it' has 7 lives after it has lived 3 days.<n>  * The second time it dies, it loses its life nr. 8 (if it had lost its life nr 8 the question would be: what if the cat has lost all eight lives?  Is it still alive?  The question is answered in section II.A below).<n>  * The third and fourth time it dies, it lose its lives on nr. 9 and 10.<n>  * So the question is:  How many lives does she have left after it has lived three days?<n>There are 7 lives (7*3=21) days  and it still had 5 lives left.  21, with the first day not counted. (It was already lost).<n><n>Input: What will you need to do with two apples

Choices:  A: expect to die B: believe in god C: stay in D: watch movies E: eat corn<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>answer = choice(('A','B', 'C', 'D', 'E'))<n>```<n>#### Output:A<n><n>### Response with Input: <n><n>```python<n>>>>> while True:<n>answer = choice(input('Enter A or B or C or D or E: '))<n>while answer not in ('A','B','C','D','E'):<n>print ('Enter true or false: ')<n>answer = input('Enter A or B: ')<n>if answer in ('A', 'B'):<n>```<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>```python<n>if "C" in choice(input('Enter C or D: ')):<n>```<n>#### Input: D<n>#### Result:  True<n><n>### Instrumentation:<n><n>#### Instructions:<n>- Add the program above and then write the code below it.<n><n><n>### Instructing:<n><n><n>### Demotion:<n><n><n>## 12/15 2021<n>

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where can the legs of a stool be built? Choices:  A: jail B: internet cafe C: blacksmith's shop D: building E: bar<n><n>### Response:		<n>A.jail<n>B.Internet cafe<n>C.blacksmith's shop<n>D.building<n>E.bar<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:What are students trying to do? Choices:  A: study philosophy B: become adult C: ask questions D: further education E: study together<n><n>### Response:		Choices: A<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Input 1: <n>The students want to become adults.<n><n>### Input2: <n>They want to further their knowledge.<n><n>### Output: <n>They're going to their professors to do that.<n><n>### Explanation: <n><n>Students in college are trying to achieve three things: become adults; further their knowledge, and study together. But the most important thing you can do to move forward is to further your knowledge. That's why you need to make sure to go to your teachers.<n><n>### Example 1:<n><n>### Answer:<n>The students are meeting with their professors to further their knowledge of philosophy.<n><n>Input: Mary is trying to make a pizza. <n>It took her 5 minutes to slice 8 tomatoes and 3 minutes to dice 7 garlic cloves. <n>How long did she spend peeling 10 potatoes?<n>Rationales If she spent 3+5+3+<<3+5=8>>8 minutes slicing 8 tomatoes, she must have spend <slicing 7 > <<slicing 7>>3 minutes slicing 7 <n>garlic cloves.<n>So If she spent 3 * 2 = <<3*2=6>>6 minutes slicing 6 garlic cloves, and 6 + 3 = <<6+3=9>>9 minutes slicing 9 potatoes, she spent 9 + 3 = <<9+3=12>>12 minutes slicing potatoes. <n>#### 12<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: Randy got paid $40 to mow the yard.  He works twice as fast as his friend, Joe, so the yard took him 1/2 as long to mow.  How long did it take Joe to mow?<n>Rationales Joe spent <mowing the yard> <<mowing the yard>><n>So (1/2 * 1/2) of the total amount of time that Randy spent taking to mow = <<1/2**2=1>>1<n>#### 1<n>Answer: 1<n><n>Answer: 155.85 degrees.<n><n>### Demo:<n>

Choices:  A: necklace B: wall outlet fixture C: tool box D: computer E: motorcycle<n><n>### Response:		What is a chain?<n><n>#### Necklace<n><n>Necklace: If a chain is a part of a necklace, the question is "fix" the necklace. "Fix" means "make something good again", "make something not broken", "repair", "replaced", or "fix".<n><n>#### Wall outlet fixture<n><n>Wall outlet fixture: If a chain is attached to a wall outlet fixture, the chain is what is fixed on it. "Fix" here means "attach", "tack", "attach", and "connect".<n><n>#### Tool box<n><n>Tool box: If a chain is the thing that is in a tool box, then the chain is made good by being screwed to the toolbox. "Fix" can be "attach", "tether", or "connect".<n><n><n>#### Computer<n><n>Computer: If fixing computer means fixing the chain on it, "Fix" means repair "repair".<n><n>#### Motorcycle<n><n>Motorcycle: If fixing a motorcycle means fixing the chain on the motorcycle, "Fix" here can be "repair", "replace", "attach", or "reattach".<n><n>### Input<n><n>#### D<n><n>Input: What is a chain?<n>Rationales<n>What is meaning by "fix" the necklaces:<n>fix (verb)- mend or repair (something): such as a clock, or a machine<n>fix (verb)- make good: such as a clock, watch, or a machine<n>Fix is the verb what have the action of mending or repaired a something.<n>In the sentence  fix a necklace means  is mending or repair a necklace.<n><n>#### C<n><n>Input: What are a chain and a chain ring?<n>Rationales A chain is used to connect something:<n>An example of "chain" in sentence: chain-link fence<n>A chain ring is a metal ring that is attached to other parts using other metals.<n><n>#### B<n><n>Input: What part of the question is confusing?<n>What is a chain? Choices:  a: a fence or watchb: a metal chainc: a part of the question itselfd: a chain ringe: none of the choices<n><n>Rationales:<n>"a fence or watch" and "a metal chain

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:How can buildings like the Empire State building be described? Choices:  A: small B: underground C: high D: huge E: tall<n><n>### Response:		I can describe the Empire State building as : Huge or Tall<n><n>### Input : What are the five main rules of algebra? Choices: <n><n>### Response : <n><n>### Input :-What part of a sentence is the object? Choices:  Nouns Verbs Pronouns Prepositions<n><n>### Response :- It is prounouns<n><n>### Input:-Which of these is a negative of 7x=3? Choices: -7x-3 7x+3 x+3/7 x-3/7 -(7x)/7<n><n>### Response:- -7x-3<n><n>### Input::Which of these numbers increases as n increases.<n><n>### Response::They are all increasing as n increases<n><n>### Inputs:-If I were you I would stop now.<n><n>### Output:-If you are me you will stop now.<n><n><n><n>### Instructions:#2<n><n>The below sections show example responses that are different from what would be expected. Use them to understand what a well-written response looks like.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>### 00.000<n><n>This answer is marked incorrect; it does not meet the passing score requirement of 4 correct.<n><n>### Score:<n><n>### Input<n>The below instructions describe a task. Write a complete sentence that adequately completes the request while conforming to the instructions and demonstrating effective communication.<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>### Instructuion<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Scoring<n><n>### Check:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:John was stuck in his house.  He couldn't get out the door.  He was very frightened when the smoke detectors went off, but luckily it was a false alarm.  Why might he be stuck? Choices:  A: fire B: belong to C: winter storm D: face south E: burn down<n><n>### Response:		He was lucky it was a false alarm, but in the future he should put a fireproof door in the house.<n><n>### Inputs:Mike goes to a restaurant where the bill was $8.75.  He gives a $20 bill and the waiter gives him $1.  The waiter then says "I'm so sorry.  May I give you a few extra dollars to pay for the inconvenience?"  What extra dollars will the waiter give Mike and at what total will the bill be due?<n><n>### Response:"No, its okay.  I'll just write you a check."<n><n>### Input :How much is 60 pounds plus 12 pounds less 17 pounds?<n>### Response : 53<n><n>#### 53<n>Answer: 53<n><n>### Input<n>How much is 32.8 percent of 5.63?<n><n>### Rationales<n>If we know that the answer is 32.14 and we need to round up to the nearest whole number. Then 32.8 < 33 and we need to round down.<n><n>We will round it down to 3 and then plug it into the original statement.<n><n>3 < 32.16 so 32.8 * 3 = <<32.8*3=100>>100<n><n>#### 100<n>Answer: 100<n><n>### Input <n>Jenna has a new phone and wants to replace it. She bought a new phone for $175. She needs to return the old one. She will receive a refund for a trade-in. She sells her old phone for $50 and also gets a $50 discount. How much profit does she make?<n><n>### Solution<n>She makes $100 profit by -Sold the phone for -Sent the phone back for -Keep the new phone and pay for it.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>She sells the phone for $50.<n>She gets a $50 back when she sends in the old phone<n>After subtract these two, she keeps $50<n>#### 50<n>Answer: $50<n><n>###Input:<n>Kate has a savings account with $4,175

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. Choices:  A: happen to people B: hurt people C: happen anytime D: happen often E: happen anywhere<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E: happen anytime.<n><n>### Rationales: "Accidents" can happen any time, anywhere.  If the lady is getting worked up about an article about accidents in her area, that implies that accidents are somehow special in her town and it is the time/place that is special.

Choices:  A: heart transplant B: distance himself C: perform surgery D: study medicine E: let blood<n><n>### Response:		<n>>B<n><n>### Input : Answer the questions based on the information below.<n><n>### Rationales : The question says which of the following is the correct response.<n><n>### Answer : B<n><n>In this case you would look at all 2017 numbers first before doing the 2016 ones. In other words, this is not an example of an ID vs. OD problem.<n><n>### Response :<n><n>#### Answer : B<n><n>### Response<n>This can be expressed as the sum of the digits of 2016 and 2017 multiplied by the first digit of each of 2018 and 2019. <n><n>### Demostration<n>1 : This is because all of the digits you are adding is 2 digits except for 2019 which is 3 digits.<n><n>2 :  The digits are not only being added together, but the value in the two different years are being multiplied by each other.<n><n>3 :  There is no subtraction. If there is an example with subtraction of the digits, then the answer would be no<n><n>### Answer: Answer 1<n><n>### Input<n>Answer the questions based on the info below:<n><n>### Rationale<n>The question is which of the following is a valid response.<n><n>## Input : <n>### Rationale : The question is asking how many times the digits in 2016, 17, 18 add up to 19. <n>  #### Answer : A<n><n>### Redeem:<n>Because 1 times 1, and 7 times 1, = 19.<n><n>### Input <n>### Rational: Is 2016 a lucky or unlucky number?<n><n>### Ratedial<n><n>#### Answer: A<n><n>### Input  <n>### Response<n><n>#### 1009<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Demo<n><n>### Demo  <n><n>### RT:<n><n>#### 12345<n>Answer: B<n>A=45<n>B=123<n>C=321<n>D=512<n><n>#### 19<n>Answer: B
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:They were competing in basketball, the goal was to what? Choices:  A: bounce the ball B: competition C: have fun D: race E: score points<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you want to learn more about this problem [Click Here for further information](https://www.mathsisfun.com/fractions/mixed-fractions.html)

If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. Choices:  A: learning B: fatigue C: mercy D: empathy E: anxiety<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is B: fatigue<n>Because fatigue was the closest answer.<n>Rationales:(1) Learning, (2) Fatigue, (3) Mercy, (4) Empathy, (5) Anxiety.<n><n>### Input<n>Judy is an avid runner, and recently she trained for an extra one kilometer each day. How many extra kilometers did she run?<n><n>### Answer:Answers vary, but they should be a multiple of 1 km.<n>The answer could be 100, 110, 120,... The answer is not unique because there are multiple options.<n><n>### Rationales<n>Judy ran 5 times a day with her standard workout consisting of a 5 km run. The day before the extra day, she ran 1 km, and then she ran 4 km in the morning.  She ran 1 km a day for the next 1 day, which was 5 km. She ran 5 km a day the day after.  On the 7th day, she ran 5 km, which took her back to completing her standard workout. In other words, she ran 10 km.<n><n>### Explanation<n>1. She finished her workout on day 6 with:  she ran 1 km for her first extra km<n><n>2. She ran a total of 11 km after finishing her normal workout on day 7.

It was an American, from where? Choices:  A: georgia B: tree C: nature D: under the rocks E: france<n><n>### Response:		The snake was an American cottonmouth (an American variety of venomous snake), that was georgia native (it is more than likely he died in this state, since we also know he was a snake and the first state the snake probably saw was the state where he was born, and Georgia is the first state in the country after the Atlantic coast) because it was a cottonmouth (we don’t know exactly where it lived, all we know is that was an american variety of snake).<n>

He could see clouds when he looked out his window.  Where might he live? Choices:  A: in books B: radio station C: city D: tower E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer must be: C<n><n>### Demnination:<n>Rationales: Clouds in this context mean that he saw them from his window. B and E are the obvious wrong choices which leave A, C, and D. James could live in a radio station if it was on top of a tall tower or in a medieval castle. James cannot live in a book because books are not on top of tall towers. James also cannot live in a city or in a tall tower because he saw clouds when he looked through his window. Therefore the answer must be C.<n><n>### Input (1/3):Molly is buying chocolates for her daughter’s birthday.  When she goes to the store, she notices that the same box costs $5 more online. How much does the box cost in total?<n><n>### Demo:<n>Rationales The same box costs $5 online more than in the store.<n>So the box costs $72 + 5 = <<$72+5=77>>77.<n>#### 77<n>Answer: 77<n><n>### Input 2/3:Molly makes cupcakes for school.  She must get enough salt as well as chocolate and sugar.  The ratios for the quantity of salt, chocolate, and sugar needed are 5:3:5.  How much more salt must she buy to make these quantities?<n><n>### Response<n><n>Answer must be C.<n>Response is C due to the fact that Molly does not have enough sugar.<n><n>### Demo<n>5:3:5 is the ratio for how much chocolate and sugar she needs for her quantities of cuppies and salt. The ratios say that for each chocolate and sugar needed for the cucpies and salt one must buy 5 and 3. In otherwords, for each cuppi needs 5 and 3 ingredients.  Cueppi = 4. This implies that she needs 5 more cuppies of salt.<n><n>### Other choices:<n><n>|Choice|Answer| |<n>|-----|-----|-------|<n>| 5 | 1 |<n>| 6 | 1 |<n><n>### Input #3:Terry is buying ice cream for a party he is having later in the day. Choices:  A: cash register B: desk drawer C: pay envelope D: throw away E: box<n><n>### Response:		If their clerk is like me they put them in the drawer<n><n>### Demos:<n>Input: John pays for his order at a store.<n>Rationales and Demos: He pays 63$ for his purchase.<n><n>1. If the first input in cash the output must be True and the input must be A.<n><n>2. If the first input is debit card the output must be True the input is B.<n><n>3. If the first input credit card the output must be False the input is C.<n><n><n>### Input<n>A person writes a check and gets food from a restaurant. Where does the clerk put the check? If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:What is love when everyone keeps feeling it? Choices:  A: contagious B: wrong C: last forever D: painful E: blind<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### A<n><n>\begin{blockquote}<n>A<n>\end{blockquote}<n><n>### Reason:<n><n>#### A:contagious<n><n>\begin{code}<n>  A: contagous<n>\end{code}<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>"It takes a person to love another person"<n><n>Love is contagious when other people are around us.<n><n>### Revision:<n><n>```<n>  *: contagious<n>```<n><n>### Revison<n><n>-  Contagious<n>- Love is not contagious.<n><n>### A:  last forever<n><n>\begin{itemize}<n>  \item A: last forever<n>\end{itemize}<n><n>#### A: last forever:<n><n>\begin{equation}<n>     A = last forever<n>      \text{Revision}<n>\end{equation}<n><n>#### Revision<n><n>-  it is possible<n>- love cannot last forever<n>- it may not last forever<n>- love cannot last<n>- love rarely last forever<n>- love often last forever<n>- love can last forever<n>- love lives forever<n>- love can never last forever<n><n>### Answer:<n><n><select id=$ansChoice1 ><option id=1>A: Contagous</option>   <option id=B>B- wrong</option>  <option id=C>C: last forever</option></select><n><input type="radio" id=radioButton3><n><input type=text id=input2 name=answer1><label>Answer:</label><n><input type='hidden' id="correctAnswer"   value="4"><n><button type=submit>Submit</button><n><n>Answer:  A<n><n>### Input2:Love is a many-splendored thing, Love lifts us up where we belong.<n><n>### Rationale2:This is a love song.<n><n>### Answer2:<n><n><select data-bind="text: $lovecss, choices: $lovechoices" style="width: 95%"><n><option value=0>Choose one answer among below:</option><n><option data-bind="text:$lovecss, options: $lovechoicel, value:4" >A: Contag
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Billy bounced the ball off the wall.  There was a target on the wall for him to bounce against.  Where might he be? Choices:  A: pool table B: toy box C: playroom D: park E: closet<n><n>### Response:		<n>C<n><n>### Instructions:<n>An animal is described below. Write a response that appropiately completes the request shown by circling the animal for each request.<n>An animal is described by the statement below.<n>It has four legs and spends its entire life in water.<n>Write a response that appropriately identifies which animal is being described.<n><n>### Exercise:<n>There is a statement below, describing an animal. Write a response below that appropriately completes this statement, naming the animal that this statement describes.<n>This animal has four legs and spiders have only two.<n>### Instrucions:<n><n>Input:  A dog and a rabbit are living in a bungalow.  They can get into and out of the house through the three doors and two windows. Choose one of the options listed below that correctly identifies how the bungalow is arranged.  Choices: A: The dog can't get out<n>B: The dog can'<n>C: The rabbit can't get out.  D<n>Rationales: Only dogs have four legs and dogs have four legs and can get into and out the house for option A<n>Only a dog and rabbit are both living in the bungalow and both have four legs for option B<n>Only a dog and a rabbit have four legs for option D<n>### Answer:<n>B<n><n>### Exercis:<n>Choose one of the options below that correctly identifies the type of cage described by the cage statement.<n>Cage statement:  It can fit a rabbit<n>Choices: A<n>Rationales: I picked A because a rabbit doesn't have fur<n><n>### Answer:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:what do you do before going to party? Choices:  A: call 911 B: enjoy yourself C: get drunk D: having sex E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		Answer choice B is correct and should be chosen<n><n>Instruction-The correct answer can be found on Page 6 of our report.<n>Rationales:"B" is the correct answer because it explains what people do before going to<n>party according to our report on page 6 of our report and it is a way to avoid<n>dangerous situation before going party.<n>#### B<n>#### B<n>Answer: B<n><n>### Input:[Choices:  A: watch horror movie B: read mystery book C: eat dinner D: watch a comedy movie E: listen to music].<n><n>### Response:[Answer choice C is correct and should be the chosen answer]<n><n>Instruction-"C" is the correct answer choice because it is a way of having fun in front<n>of screen.<n><n>#### C<n>#### C<n>Answer: C<n><n>### Input<n>#### 701<n>### Response<n><n>Instruction-701 is the correct answer because the time in the movie is 701 seconds.<n><n>#### 70<n>#### 70

He felt that he'd ruin his relationship with Jen if he took it further, and he didn't want to do that.  At the same time,  He fight that pushing farther might do what to something good? Choices:  A: found B: destroy C: construct D: fix E: produce<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>def ruining_relationship(james):<n>	if(james=="James didn't know (what to do). He felt like he'd ruin (his relationship with Jen) if she took it (further) but he didn't want (to) do that. How many years would it take for the population to increase by 1200 people? <n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```python<n>population = float(input("What is population of the city you want to simulate: "))<n>rise = 149 <n>year = 0 <n>n_years = 0<n>while(population < 1200):<n>	if (year >= 999): <n>		pass<n>	else:<n>    	year += 1 <n>    population += rise <n>	print("Year: ", year, rise," Population: ", population) <n>	n_years += 1 <n>while (year < 999):<n>	year += 1<n>	if (year < 39):<n>		rise =  - 1<n>	else: <n>		rise  += 3<n>print("Year: ", 999," Population: ", population," Number of Days: ",n_years) <n>```<n><n>#### Answer: 21 <n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input:  If I started with 20 pounds, and I weigh twice as much in 10 months, then in 15 months my weight will be 50 pounds.<n><n>Define and use the recurrence T(n) to compute the value of n as the time it takes a person weigh twice as much as another

Choices: A: a set is a collection of objects that contains all the possible properties and subproperties of those objects B: a set is a group of things that are similar or that contain something in common C: a set is a distinct collection of things that have a common property or that share something in common D: a set is a category B: a set is category<n><n>#### 3<n>Answer: 3<n><n>### Response :<n>Pick the choice that correctly follows the rule in the given statement. Choices: A:[3]<[5] and [5]<[9]<n>E:[3]=[9] and [5]>_[3]<n>G:1<4=1<<a, but 1=<c<n>L:1=2<n>Answer: L:1=2<n><n>### Instraction : What is the output of the given procedure?<n><n>#### 2<n>Answer: 2<n><n><n><n><n><n>### Instructs:<n>What is the answer to the following math test?<n><n>>**Problem 1**<n>><n>>Input: 694112<n>>Output: 145542719151512<n><n>```python<n>import math<n>def pprint(num, digits):<n>    s=''<n>    v=pow(10,digits)<n>    for x in range(num // v):<n>        s+=str(num//v)+"*10^"+ str(digits - x-1)+"="<n>    return s<n><n>for i in range(0,len(input

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where will a native lemur be found? Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Input<n>What time does your math class end? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:What do humans do when they want to reproduce? Choices:  A: eat ice cream B: have sex C: sit down D: make mistakes E: hear sounds<n><n>### Response:		<n>C: sit down<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that correctly completes each of these instructions. Each response should specify how many gallons of gas it takes to drive a car for exactly 60 miles.<n><n>#### 1<n>Write a response that specifies how many gallons of fuel it takes to drive car 1 to go exactly 60 miles<n> <n>#### 2<n>Write a response that completes the instructions<n>```<n>Write a response that describes a gas cost.<n><n>Write a response.<n>```<n>#### 3<n>Write a response that correct answers the request.<n>```<n>What is the cost to buy this car?<n>```<n>#### 4<n>Write a response that answers the questions<n>```<n>What is 2 + 2?<n>```<n>#### [5]<n>Write a response that uses a rational and logically answers the questions<n>``` <n>How many miles does the car travel?<n>```<n><n>**125 miles<n><n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where is a monkey likely to be found in the rainforest? Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		Monkey is likely to be found in: A: rain forest<n><n>Monkey is likely to be _______________________ a tree.<n>A: in<n><n>### Input<n><n>Every day Tom drinks 4 7-oz cans of beer plus 36 ounces of water, 4 apples, and 2 carrots. Choices:  A: pass water B: bathe C: listen to each other D: feel pleasure E: reproduce asexually<n><n>### Response:		B, The animals weren't able to bathe.<n><n><n>### Answer Key:<n>The answer is B, animals weren’t able to bathe because they were poor swimmers!<n><n>### Demand:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>Input: You made $20,000 in salary this year and will have to pay $12,000 in federal taxes. Your marginal tax rate is the additional tax you pay on every dollar of your money you make. If your tax rate was 40% how much did you make this year?<n><n>Rationales: (Assuming a linear demand function.)<n>I've set up this scenario to look like what you'll see for a demand question.<n>Suppose $12000 of my taxes would apply to the first $20000. <n>(I assume $10000 of my salary is considered below the tax range and that taxes get capped on the income above the range of $2000.)<n>100*12*10000 + 40*2000 = 1200. (Assuming $1000 of your taxes on your first $1000.)<n>$10000 - $2000 = $8000. (The rest is considered the range that would be taxed at $1000 a dollar.)<n>8000/12 = 666 (The amount of taxes paid for every additional $1000 you get in pay.)<n>$8000/666 = 12030 ( The income above the tax applied range.)<n>$20000/$666=$3072

Choices:  A: opened B: closed C: found at shower D: falling down E: locked<n><n>### Response:		It needs to be C, found at shower<n><n>### Input.Two people played a dice game. For each turn, they rolled a dice. If the dice's number was 2 then the first person scored 1 point and the first person scored 2 points. At which point did they earn more points?<n><n>### Rationale:Dice. 1=12, 2=23, 3=34, 4=45, 5=56 and 6 = 66.  There are multiple possible ways to earn 6 more points than the second person.<n>They will get the 66+2=<<66+2=88>>88 points.<n>### Input:Two people played a dice.  They roll it 1-6 times.  To win, they must roll the number 2 exactly twice.  What is the probability that it happened?<n><n>### Response:(b)<n><n>### Rationales:In 6^2 cases, 3^3, you need exactly 2 turns and you will not get 66 points or 33 points.<n><n>In 6^2 = 36 total cases you had to roll 2<n><n>(6/6)^2 = 1/4<n><n>6/4 x 1/4=<<6/4*1/4=1>>1 probability of winning<n><n>### Input=A car travels 573 miles in one tank of gas that costs $3.25 per gallon and weighs 6.7 pounds per gallon.  What is the average price per mile of gas the car uses each gallon?<n><n>### Answer=(755/573) * 3.25=<<3.25/573=0.059>>0.0595 or about $0.06<n><n>### Input<n>How many times did John wake up during the night in an 8-hour sleep?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>1 - It is 8 hours, he slept for 8 hours without waking up. That is 8-0 = <<8-0=8>>8<n>2 - He slept for 8.5 hours, woke up 5 times -> 8.5

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:The disease was spreading fast, so what were researchers desperately seeking? Choices:  A: cause spots on leaf B: healthy C: wellness D: ball stopped E: cure<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explanation: The disease was spreading fast. Choices A, B, C, and E all focus on the "sick" or infirm. "Leaf" is implied by the presence of leaf spots, as well as by the reference to "leaf." "Wellness" also covers the disease, but suggests an improvement of normal health, rather than a cure. "Ball" is also suggested by the presence of "cause spots on leaf." "Cure" implies both improvement and removal. So the correct answer is A.<n><n>### Testing:<n><n>```<n>A: cause spots on the leaf<n>B: healthy<n>C: wellness<n>D: ball stops<n>E: cure<n><n>A: cause spotes on the leaf<n>B,C,D are all false<n><n>B: healthy, cure, wellness<n>B, C, D, E are both false<n><n>C: wellness, cure  <n>Wellness and cure both true<n><n>D: ball stop <n>False<n><n>E: cure, wellness  <n>False<n><n>Choose Choice A: cause spots<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```<n>Davina is sick with measles. It is spreading on the farm and on her family, so what were researches desperately seeking? Which one is correct?<n>```<n>```<n>I. a cause for the disease<n>false<n><n>II. a cure for the disease<n>Yes<n><n>Is it B? healthy?<n>Is it C? wellness?<n>Is it A? cause spots on leaf?<n>Is it D? a ball?<n><n>Yes<n><n>False<n><n>No<n><n>Yes.<n><n>B+868-819<n>E-56<n>E-27<n>D-180<n>A+0<n>A=10<n>A+300<n><n>C+0 <n>false<n><n>E+0<n>C+30<n><n>false<n><n>B+0<n><n>```<n><n>## DQ-1<n><n>## Q-2<n><n>## DQ--2<n><n>### Demosc:<n><n>```<n>Write a program that asks a user to input an integer with only one digit that is not the number 10. If the user enters any other number
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. Choices:  A: fish market B: hawaiian waters C: gulf of mexico D: tropical sea E: south pacific ocean<n><n>### Response:		Because johnny is looking for blowfish in the oceans I believe D because a fish market can sell any kind of fish the gulf of Mexico was tropical so b is out c is too far out which is E I believe D to be correct.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Nowadays people have smart ones, but at one time it was cutting edge to have a tiny calculator on your what? Choices:  A: mobile phone B: wristwatch C: briefcase D: office E: desktop<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### A)<n>####  mobile<n>Answer:  mobile<n><n>### B)<n>####  wristwatch<n>Answer:  wristwatch<n><n>### C)<n>####  briefcase<n>Answer:  briefcase<n><n>### D)<n>####  office<n>Answer:  office<n><n>### E)<n>####  desktop<n>Answer:  desktop<n><n>### Demostration 1:<n><n>### Input 1:<n><n>#### $12$<n>#### $<<5$>>5<n><n>### Rationales<n>#### <n>#### $<<12*5=$50$>>50<n>#### Answer:  $50$<n><n>### Demonsation 2:<n><n>### Instruccion 2<n>Input: Adam paid $75 for that car. A loan officer said he'd need to put down $1,100 in cash. He has an auto loan for $19,300, and now, if he wants this car, he'll need to come up with a lot more cash.<n>Rationales<n>#### 75<n>#### 1100<n><n>### Demetasion 3<n><n>### Instructio 3:<n><n>### Instrutcion 3:What did you do for your first day of sophomore year? Specifically I think I improved in my writing ability. Before doing this project I never really thought about my grammar, usage, or clarity of sentences. After I realized that this project was not like a standard project that the language arts teacher required i was really motivated to do it well and put what i had learned previously about writing to

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where do you go to meet a friend who lives close to you? Choices:  A: workplace B: bus station C: social atmosphere D: neighbor's house E: at school<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### 14111111<n>Answer: E: at school<n>input:<n>If the number of years of work experience an individual has is less than 30, then the individual is a youth, otherwise the individual is an adult.<n><n>Input: Mary has worked for four years.  Is she a youth, an adult, or both?<n><n>Rationales: She is not an adult, because if she was an adult she would have at least 30 years of work experience.<n>She is not a youth because she does not have less than 30 years of experience<n>#### 13<n>Answer: Both A and B<n><n>### Input:(In this challenge the only way to complete the request is to provide a wrong answer which is "Fair enough).<n>In his previous job he made $75 an hour. He now makes $60 per hour less than that.  How many hours did he used to make?<n><n>### Solution:<n>No matter what he makes, 75/6-60/6=<?75/6-120/6>=12<n>If he makes 60/6, 75/8=<<75/8=9>>9<n>If he makes 70/6, 85/8=<<85/8=10>>10<n>If he makes 80/6, 175/8=20,000<n>There is a typo in the sentence that says: No matter what he makes, $$75/6-<<60/6=12>>12$$. It should be 75/3<n><n>### Input:"Fair enough.  How long did he live? Choices:  Under 12 hours, 12-24 hours Under 24 hours, 24-48 hours, More than 48 hours<n><n>### Response:"Fair enough.<n><n>### Input."A bicycle needs to be in motion to move.
