If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where would I put a rosebush if I did not have any containers to store it in? Choices:  A: flower garden B: garden center C: pot D: pot E: formal garden<n><n>### Response:		Putting a rosebush in the formal garden would be the best choice.<n><n>### Explanation and Reasoning:<n><n>![Image of formal flower garden](./assets/formalFlowerGarden.png)<n><n>![Image of garden center](./assets/gardenCenter.png)<n><n>This rosebush would be ideal in a pot<n><n>![Image of pot](./assets/pot.png)<n><n>I do not have any more choices A.<n><n>![Image of flower garden](./assets:flowergarden.png)<n>![Image of the garden center](./assets:gardenCenter.png)!<n>![Image of the rosebush in the center](./assets:rosebush.png)<n><n>There is no way I can put another plant in its place.<n><n>![Image when there is only one flower in the garden](./assets/onefloer.png)<n><n>So the rosebush would be placed in the garden center.<n><n>### Rationales:The formal garden lacks a rosebush. <n>There is no room inside or outside for flower gardens.<n>The garden center only has room for one rosebush from all the flower options given.<n><n>#### Solution:<n>[FormalFlowerGarden](./assets/formFlowerGarven.png)<n><n>The garden center<n><n>[GardenCentre](./assets/gardanceCentre.png)<n><n>Pot<n><n>[FlowersInAPot](./assets/flowerInApot.png)<n>\$\&\$\<n><n>Answer: Input: What is the sum of 72 and 96?<n>Response: Answer: 168<n><n>## Rationales:<n><n>![Example of a rosebush](./assets/flowers.png)<n><n>### Demographics:<n><n>12-year-old girl<n><n>12-100-year-old man<n><n>### Input/Output Examples:<n><n>### Write a mathematical instruction that appropriately completes this statement.<n><n>Input: Add the numbers 1 + 1.<n><n>Response: 1 + 1 = 2<n><n>Input: Subtract 64 from 65.<n><n>Response:<n><n><n>64 - 65 = -1<n><n>### Write
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Bob needs a level to hang a shelf but cant find one in his home. How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Sarah opened his chest and found a second heart.  Her patient might not be what? Choices:  A: istanbul B: animal C: antique shop D: human being E: bedroom<n><n>### Response:		D<n><n>### Demand<n>### <n><n>###<n>###<n><n>###<n><n>```<n>#!/bin/bash<n>i=$1<n>if [[ $i -ne "0" && $i -ne "5" && $i -gt "0" && $if -le "5" ]]; then<n>	eval $i<n>else<n>	echo > "/dev/null"<n>fi<n>```
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where do most people keep their curling iron stored? Choices:  A: bathroom B: walkway C: use D: hair salon E: drawer<n><n>### Response:		Choice B<n><n>### Instrucation:<n><n>### Demomstion:<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Input: If 50% of the shoppers prefer grocery store A over grocery store B, then 50% of people will buy from store A and 50% will buy from store B.<n>Rationales<n>There are 100 shoppers<n>50 of them will buy from store A, and 50 of them will<n>store B<n>50/50=<<50/50>>0.5 of the buyers will buy from store A<n>45/100=<<45/10=4.5>>4.5% of the buyers will<n><n>#### 4.5%<n>Answer: 0.045<n><n><n><n>### Input Choices<n>Where do most people keep [ ] their curling iron? Choices: A: bathroom B 0  walkway C 0 u  salon E: drawe [0 ] <n>14% of people Keep their curling iron in the bathroom<n><n>Input: There ae 1000 grocery stores in Los Angeles.  Every 75% of grocery<n>stores have more than 50 shoppers.  Where do most people shop for groceries?<n><n>### Input<n>Input Choices:  A) Food4Less B 0  Marketplace C 0 superstores D E Fresh <n>Fresh Supermarket has more than 50% of  shoppers<n>Fresh Supermarket is the answer<n><n><n># 0.04% 0.04% <a href="/home.html"> < </a> -Home

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Everybody raised a drink and cheered, they were doing what? Choices:  A: were thirsty B: toasting C: getting drunk D: refreshment E: celebrating<n><n>### Response:		The right answer is: D.They were getting drunk<n><n><n># DATA-DRIVEN DECISION-MAKING<n>Write a response that appropriately does the following.<n><n>### Input<n>We have a big problem. There are tons of traffic.<n><n>### Our current solution<n><n>#### We will use the following to try and minimize the effects of the traffic on our citizens by creating a new solution that allows for the lessening of the effects of the traffic.<n><n>## Feedback:The current solution doesn't work well.<n><n># COGNITIVE RESILIENCE<n><n>Write a response that contains explanations of the task you were given below. You may also write a response that provides alternative task instructions than what was given.<n><n>Exercise:<n><n>Input: Everybody raised a drink and _____, they were _________.<n><n>Choices: A: were thirst B: toasting<n><n>Rationales: It sounds like they were getting drunk.<n><n>## Explanation:<n><n>For the toasting option, they were toasting people. In other words, congratulating someone. For the thirsty option, they were thirsty from drinking. For the getting drunk, they were getting drunk due to drinking a lot of alcohol. For the lesson, they were making fun of the driver. (Making fun of the driver and getting drunk are correct.)<n><n>

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:John is getting something important.  What does this make him feel? Choices:  A: then have B: headaches C: stoic D: being happy E: wanting more<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Demo:<n>Input: 12.5*6 = <<12.5*12.5=156.25>>156.2<n>Output: 156.2 answer<n><n>### Instructions: Calculate the following without a calculator.<n><n>### Answer: 73<n>---<n><br><n><n>##### Q:What is 1 divided by 0.25? __ __<n><n>###### Rationales __ __ __<n><n>Input: 5*12*20/2=<<20*20*5/2=200>>200 answer<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Input 1:<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>###### Instructions:<n><n>### Instuction: The instructions do not contain any mathematical operations and just provide several lines or pieces of information (e.g., dates, people, times, names, organizations, numbers).<n><n>###### Instruction:Answer the question.<n><n>###### Question:When, who, and where?<n><n>###### Demonstration:Write a response that appropriately answer the question.<n><n>## Instructions: <n><n>Write a recursive function that asks the user for a positive number until the user provides a number that is not an integer, and then outputs a positive integer that is divisible by the last two numbers provided by the user.<n>

Choices:  A: advertisement B: magazine C: store D: web page E: bus<n><n>### Response:		His job is not dancing and waving to advertisements. Since dancing and waving advertisements are not jobs, so the possible options must be: B, D, E The answer must go into letter format and only include the correct letter.<n>#### A:<n>\[<n>\begin{aligned}<n><n>\mbox{A}: \mbox{ } \text{dancing and waving advertising} \\\\<n>\end{aligned}<n>\]<n><n>#### B:<n>\[<n><n>\mbox{B}: \mbox{ } dancing and waving \\\\<n>\mbox{ a magazine} <n>\]<n><n>#### C:<n>\[<n> \mbox{C}: \mbox{ }dancing and waving \text{store} <n>\]<n>#### D:<n>\[<n>  \mbox{D}: \mbox{ }   dancing and waving  \text{web page}  \\\\<n>\]<n><n>#### E:<n>\[<n>   <n> \mbox{E}:  \text{dancing\& waving \text{bus}}} <n>\]<n><n><n><n>### Expected Behavior<n>- Answers should include a mathematical calculation with the requested input and an answer in a reasonable format.  The final answers should be in the form of $<integer><integer>$.<n>- Answers should be clear enough for another person to read and understand easily. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: spinning wheel B: on a ladder C: hospital bed D: legroom E: grand piano<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A.<n><n>The input, ‘Where does someone lay with a broken leg?’ can be rearranged to ‘With a broken leg, does someone lay down? <n>Those who lie or lay down on a spinning wheel are considered broken leg. <n>So, the correct answer is A.

Choices:  A: shelf B: desktop C: cabinet D: kitchen E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		I will put the mug into the cabinet<n><n>### Input and output: <n><n>#### Input: You can have 20 of my books, which 20 books do you choose?<n><n>**Options:**<n>* Sword and axe,<n>* King's crown,<n>* Dwarf's helmet,<n>* Unicorn horns<n><n>#### Output:<n><n>> Sword and axe<n><n>### Input/Output: <n>#### Input and output:<n>What animal's hide would you want to have? Which do you like the best?<n><n>• Shops<n><n>• Malls<n><n>#### Choices<n><n>Choices: Shops<n><n>#### Instruction and Demo:<n><n><n>### Input<n><n>Which country would you like to visit?<n><n>- India<n>- China<n>- Australia<n>- Cuba<n><n>Your next trip will be...<n><n>#### Demo:<n><n>#### Instructions<n><n>#### Instruction #5<n><n>Input and Demo:<n><n>#### Demo:   <n><n>#### Options:<n><n><n>#### Instrucciones:<n> <n>*  - Option1<n>*  - Option2<n>*  - Option3<n><n>#### Demonstracin:<n><n>Option 1<n>Option 2<n>Option 3<n><n><n><n><n>### Instructions<n>Input:<n>You have finished all sections of the exam, the total score is 259.<n><n>Which section scored the highest?  Which scored the lowest?  If you scored well, you will be awarded $50.  If you did not score well, you failed the exam.<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>Highest score
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:John is a human who is in a wheelchair due to an accident.  Where would he go to get to the third floor of his apartment building? Choices:  A: space shuttle B: detroit C: stairs D: downtown E: elevator<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>John would choose to use a detroit as its too easy to choose stairs.<n>But elevators are also more appropriate he cant use a space shuttle because he has a wheel chair.<n>He cant use a Detroit because it doesn't have accessibly ramps or stairs that he can use when he arrives.<n>He cannot use the stairs because he is a person in a wheelchair and its a bit too hard to get up.<n>But he would rather get that than struggle on the elevator.<n>He cant go to Detroit because the buildings all over detroit is so close to each other and because he has a wheelchair he needs to take a detroit so that it can carry him on top of him.<n><n>#### Options:E<n>Answer:E

Choices:  A) regular wood pencil B) #2 pencil C) mechanical pencil D) watercolor set  E) colored pencils<n><n>### Response:: Well you need a regular wood pencil or anything that is like a regular wood pencils I think<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the question that appropriately completes each request.<n><n>## Conclusion<n>What is this assignment really about?<n><n>  - The ability to identify the important details in order to interpret the situation correctly<n>  - The ability apply the knowledge that you have in answering the question correctly<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:James is very interested in other planets.  He loved the idea of going to mars, and reads books about it all the time.   He dreams of being on what? Choices:  A: love B: zoo C: school D: space shuttle E: library<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is A.<n><n>### Explanation:Planet means that place where you want to be.  And it relates to the word school since in space he was in space shuttle to the planet mars.<n><n>### The other answers are incorrect.<n><n>### Input : You'd better make this your last time buying those expensive cigarettes!  You've paid more than 2000 dollars in the last two years!<n><n>### Response : How much more?<n><n>### Explenation:First make sure the cigarettes are more expensive compared to money paid<n>

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:James was looking for a place to buy bitcoins. Choices:  A: get angry B: concern C: worrie D: education E: learning about world<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### C<n><n>A is incorrect because if you get angry, then you may not want to read a newspaper. B is incorrect because you may not be concerned about the current events. And D is incorrect because there's no way that you learn how to write in your sleep. Even if you are not trying to teach yourself how to write, you won't learn anything that is not in the newspaper. It should have a constructor "TimeRemaining(long)", two methods "TimeRemaining.isZero()" and "TimeRemaining.secondsToWait()", and two properties "TimeRemaining.minutes" and "TimeRemaining minSeconds." The program should return "true" if the time remaining is 0, but must otherwise return "false." It should return the number of seconds remaining when the constructor is called with a given time and it should use minSeconds to display how many minutes and seconds remain when TimeRemaining is used to compute wait time. In the end, write an application that connects to devices via Bluetooth, reads information about the hardware, and displays the information using the methods of My App.<n>#### 3.<n><n>### Solution:<n>The constructor takes in a long and it is stored as a long value. The two methods are isZero and secondsToWait. The isZero method takes the remaining time and compares that time to a value of zero. That is false. Otherwise that value is passed to the other method called  secondsToWait and that method takes the total time and subtract the remaining time so that you can determine the time remaining.<n><n>

Write a response to the task.<n><n>### Response 1:<n>In the Carolinas, the blowfish is found in the sea of japan<n><n>### Response2:<n>In the Carolines, the blowfish was found at the sea of japan.<n><n>### Task:<n>John wants to make his wife 100 cupcakes (from scratch) but he doesn't want to bake all on one day. His baking skills are limited and he only has the one mixing bowl. The answer is 2 since 19 and 29 contain a 9.<n><n>### A:<n>1<n><n>### B:<n>The number 9 is the number of<n><n>### C:<n>6<n><n>### D:<n>2<n><n>### E:<n>3<n><n><n>### Output:<n>Output is the function <n>Task:2<n><n>Task:1<n><n>Task:6<n><n>Task:2<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:What area is likely to contain a large village? Choices:  A: rural area B: big city C: suburbs D: ohio E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		Write a letter that properly codes a response to the request.<n>If an exact match between the choice and the place where the large village is located cannot be found, use "E".<n><n>| Choices  || Answer|<n>|:---------:|:-------:|<n>| A        || D       |<n>| B        || E       |<n>| C        || C       |<n>| D        || A       |<n>| E        || B       |<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Shane was supposed to speak at his fathers funeral.  He was a clown, and acted very ridiculous.  This cheerfulness turned off people who expected the funeral to be what? Choices:  A: solemn B: compete C: serious D: somber E: straightforward<n><n>### Response:		4<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Input 1 is the sum of a given pair of numbers.  Choose an answer that most accurately states what the output, 3, is the sum of.<n><n>### Ex: 3 is the sum of <<3 is the sum of 8+5>>8+5 and 3 is the sum  of 3+1>>3+1<n>### Rationales: Since 8 and 5 are both odd and their sum is even, 8+5 must be even, 8+7(odd) = <<8+7=55>>55 is also even.  The sum of 55+3=<<55+3=58>>58<n>#### 58<n>Answer: 58<n><n>### Instructios:<n>Input 2 is the sum of a set of numbers.  Choices a-d show the inputs to the function. Choices:  A: rain forest B: research laboratory C: cage D: treetops E: south africa<n><n>### Response:		 B, C, D, E<n>Answer: 5<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Input: The number of goals C.W. scored in a game last season accounts for 40% of the team's goals. If the number of goals he scored in all other games accounted for another 31% of the team'S goals.  What percentage of the team's total goals did he score?<n><n>## Rationales:If he scored the C.W. scored the team'S total goals divided by the goal that he scored and the C.W. and the team'S total divided by 1.825, 31 divided by the team's total.<n><n>### Answer: 16.2%<n><n>### Insturctions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>## Instruction:  Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n><n>## Input 1: In the last election, a candidate received 54% of the votes cast in a precinct.  How many votes did the candidate receive?<n><n>## Rationale: The number of how many votes the candidate got is 54%.<n><n>## Answer: 312<n><n>## Instruction 2: How many women over the age of 50 were enrolled at school last year?<n><n>## Input: 300 students were enrolled at school.  The breakdown by gender (given as percentages) is:<n>- Men 59%<n>- Over 50 Females 10%<n>- Over 36 Females 31%<n>- Under 20 Females 7%<n>- Over 20 Females: 1%<n><n>## Rationale If you sum all the percentages you get 0.871 which is the same as: 87% women over the age of fifty were enrolled.  We subtract 59% which get you 28%, the remainder of the women not included in the other numbers.  Then you divide 100%-59% by the percent of males (59%) to get the remainder.<n><n>## Rationale 2: If you divide 101-7 by 7 it gets you 5 and that is the remainder when the percentages equal 100%.

Choices:  A: hardware store B: basement C: garage D: repair shop E: the library.<n><n>### Response:		In the basement<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Description:<n><n>Write an expression to compute the length of "a rectangle with width 9 cm and length that is 10 cm more than 3 times the width."<n><n>## Examples:<n><n>```<n>width = 9<n>length = 11<n><n>answer = 10 + 3 * (9/10) = <<10+3*3/10=3/10>>3/10<n>```<n><n>```<n>width  = 5<n>length = 15<n><n>answer = 7+3 * 5 = <<5*3=15>>15<n>```<n><n>## Rationale for the solution:<n><n>```<n>a rectangle with width 15 cm + 3 cm and length that is a rectangle with width 9.<n>```<n><n>```jsx<n>var width = 16<n>var length = 12<n><n>var answer = length - 3 * width / 10 = <<12-3*9/10=5/10>>5/10<n>```

How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where does a shadow usually appear? Choices:  A: suface of moon B: building C: bridge D: ground E: bright light<n><n>### Response:		C.B.D<n><n>### Demotraction: Choice B is the correct one<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:George ruined the surprise.  How did he do so? Choices:  A: hiding B: accidentally C: expectation D: knowingly E: planned<n><n>### Response:		The answer is A<n><n>### Instructions and response:<n><n>### Instructon:Choose and complete the appropriate alternative:<n><n>#### Rationales:<n>A: In his house, George has hidden the surprise in the same place every time.  Invariably, each time, it gets found.<n><n>#### Response:<n>B: George accidentally let it slip that he knows.<n><n>#### Rational:<n>C: George accidentally mentioned the surprise.<n><n>#### Response in place:<n>D: George told his friends what the surprise is all about.<n><n>**A.** **In his house, George has hid the surprise in the same** place **every time. Invariably, each **time, it gets found**.<n><n>**B.** **George accidentally let it sip that he knows**<n><n>**C.** **George accidetnally mentioned the surprise**<n><n>**D.** **George told his friends what the surprises is all about**<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: Insurance coverage is based on the deductible, premium, and the out-of-pocket maximum. Deductibles for certain plans vary and out-of-pockets maximums also vary by plan. <n>How do you determine your out-of-pocked expenses? Choices: a) multiply out-of-pocke maximum * (deductible of plan)* plan premium b) take the out-of-paper maximum and deduct it from the total expenses c) add up your out-of-poccket expenses and then deduct the premium from that amount d) divide the out-of-pcket expenses by deductible and multipy by premium.<n><n><n>### Solution<n><n><n>**A** [multiply out-of-poke maximum * (deductsble of plan)* plan premiums]: $<< out-of-pooce-maximums * (deductible) * premium>> premiums<n><n>**B** [take the out-of-pack expenses and then dedict it from the total expences ]: $<<take out-of-poce-maximums and then dedicect>> it from the total expencees<n><n>**C** [add up your oout-of poccket epsences and then
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where do fish spend the majority of their time? Choices:  A: body of water B: lake superior C: underwater D: toilet E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		C<n>

How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where above your kitchen sink could you store canned food? Choices:  A: cupboard B: oven C: grocery store D: pantry E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		Choice D<n><n>Input: Where above your kitchen sink could store canned food?<n>Choice:<n><n>Choice B: oven is not a space for canned food<n><n>Choice C: grocery is also not a place for canned foods<n><n>Choice E: cellar is too far away and is not a good place for canned food<n>We need foods from below grade and cellar is below that.<n><n>Choice D: Pantry is the only choice that fit our requirement:<n><n>Canned food should be stored in a dry place and pantry is dry space<n><n>Canned foods are easy to access from pantry and can be use for food storage<n><n>A: Pantry B: Cellar C: Oven D: Grocery Store E: Pantry<n><n>Choice D: Answer: Pantry<n><n>### Input :<n>How much of the water you drink a week comes from a fountain?<n><n>### Choice:<n>- A: 40%<n>- B: 20%<n>- C: 60%<n>- D: 30%<n>- E: 10% <n><n><n><n>- A: <n>- B: <n>- C: <n>- D: <n>- E: <n>```<n><n>Answer Choice D<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where is a road known as a motorway? Choices:  A: scotland B: europe C: race track D: new jersey E: england<n><n>### Response:		The UK has a few roads that have been branded with the term motorway, yet there is only one major road in America that is known as a motorway.<n><n>### In the United States, a motorway is often known as a highway. Even on the main sites that provide US highway maps, such as Wikipedia and the US Federal Highway Administration, a map indicates that there is one motorway in the United States. This is known as the NYS Thruway, which is called an expressway by the US Department of Transportation.<n><n>### However, the European Motorway Code and other European Union documents, as well as most Europeans, would not consider the term motorway to refer to this US road.<n><n>### Why? A highway is the most commonly-used term for a major road in the United States. It is used synonymously with motorway, and has its base in a French word that means way, highway or track.<n><n>### A motorway is also commonly used in Europe, but the US does not often use that term. Even as US highways transition to the use of tolls to finance their upkeep and increase in traffic, it has not changed the terminology yet.<n><n>### When discussing roads worldwide, the most accepted terminology will be to use specific national terminology.  The term motorway is a British term commonly used to refer to major roads, whereas highway, interstate, route, or expressway are more acceptable terms to use in the US.  In the meantime, you would be unlikely to meet American driving instructors or travel experts using the term motorway in their advice or recommendations, although they may use it in conversation if asked.<n><n>### The US uses the term interstate to refer to some roads (see [map](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Map_of_U.S._interstate_highways)).<n><n>### Choice A: Scotland<n>#### Scotland has some roads that are referred to as motorways, but not as main arteries of transportation.<n><n>##  Task Analysis:<n>Input: A pizza costs $25 at one restaurant and $12 at another. If the two restaurants double the amount of pizza ordered, what is the ratio of the cheaper price to the more expensive price?<n>So at the first restaurant, you would pay 25*2
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:How might compassionate thoughful be described as being? Choices:  A: disengenious B: human C: weird D: kind E: stupid<n><n>### Response:		<n>####  C)<n>Answer:  A<n><n>

Choices:  A: mouth B: jars and all faces C: kentucky fried chicken D: hand E: human<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A<n>2. B<n>3. D<n>4. E<n>5. A<n><n>### Solution:<n>1. The lips are on the mouth<n>2. The lips are inside the jars and they are part of faces<n>3. One can say that the lips are on the human hand, but not part of a human face.<n>4. The lips are on a Kentucky Fried Chicken, so they are part of a face.<n>5. The lips are on mouth, so they are part the human face.<n><n>### Reason<n>All the choices are lips are "on" human body, except option "E" which is human lips are "part" of a human body.<n><n>### Input<n><n>A man is the father of 3 children, two daughters named Sarah and Amy and a son named George. What was the price of 1 shirt and 1 pair of pants?<n><n>### Reponse<n>1. 66588.999 = <<66588=3>>366,466,69 1 shirt  2. 68327.999 = "1"<n>3. 688,631.999 = 3<n><n>### Dem<n>#### 64, 66, 68.999<n>Answer: 6, 7, 8<n>

It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:If you hit someone while driving what could happen to that person? Choices:  A: deaths B: get arrested C: moving D: using gas E: may die<n><n>### Response:		In order to hit someone while driving, one would have to hit someone. That would cause some type injury to that driver. So choices A, C, and D will be the correct answer to this problem.  However, choice A and B were a bit too far out there, so they were eliminated.<n><n>### Input<n>If someone eats 1 apple, 3 grapes, 5 bananas, 7 pieces of fruit a week, how many weeks until they have eaten 500 pieces of fruit?<n><n>### Response<n>The total number of pieces of fruit is 1+3+5+7=16.  Therefore, the total number of weeks it takes to consume 16 pieces of fruit is 500/16 =<<500/15=33.33>>33.33 weeks.<n><n>### Answer<n>16<n><n>### Inputs & Responses<n>What is the total of the value of each letter? (A: $5.10, B: $9.80).<n><n>### Response/Coding<n>It is clear from the description that the responses should be the same since they are the values for the same letters.  Therefore, the value of the 1st letter is 5.10, and the value of the 2nd letter is 9.80.  So the total is 5.1+9.8 = 15.9.<n><n>### Response / Coding<n>What is the total value of these three sentences (E: 41, H: 38, L: 82, I:25).<n><n>### Solution / Coding<n>I don't like HELPING YOU!!!<n>I don't either<n><n>### Response <n>L<n><n>### Input / Response<n>What is the total cost of all of these?<n><n>### Solution<n>195<n><n>### Input/Response<n>The total of these is 136 (113 plus 113+113)<n><n>### Coding Solution<n>136<n><n>### Response Input / Solution<n>How long will it take them to finish 12 bags every day?<n>This problem can really be simplified to solving for n.  If one of them finishes 1
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:You'd add pepper and salt to what liquid meal if it's bland? Choices:  A: supermarket B: water C: cellars D: soup E: grocery store<n><n>### Response:		Choices:  E: grocery<n><n>#### A: supermarket B C: water D: soup<n><n>#### E: grocery E: grocery Mixed 1: A: supermarket C: water<n><n>### Demerger:For the nut question, the answer is 56, and you didn't include the rationales.<n><n>### Input For a demo:You have 40 pounds of tomatoes, how many kilograms are there? How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. Choices:  A: university B: college class C: class room D: classroom E: library<n><n>### Response:		He might spent most of his time E: classroom A:library<n><n>### Rationales:  A: university<n><n>C: class room<n><n>####  Library<n><n>D: classroom<n><n>### Instructor-Provided: Answer the following multiple choice question correctly.<n><n>### Input:(x+3)+(6-2x)-4x<n><n>### Response:(x+3)(6-2x)+4x<n><n>## Rational: The given expression contains parentheses, so the distributive property needs to be used to remove them.  The question gives us the answer choices in the format of (x+3) and ((6-2x)+x)+4x<n>So we can use distributive property to rewrite the expression:<n>1) Distributive property can be used to rewrite the left parenthesis:  x+(x+3)+(x+3)(6)<n>2) Distributive property on the next term is applied to get a term (6-2x) + (x+3)*(6-2x)<n>3) The last step applies the distributive property on the right parenthesis to end with a final product of: ((x+3)*(10 )+(4))+4x<n><n>## Input: What fraction of water does a bottle have to refill if it's quarter is filled completely? How many quarters are needed to refill the bottle?<n>#### Water Fraction<n><n>The answer represents the amount of water in a bottle that is filled to its maximum capacity after pouring the water in 1 quarter<n><n>The answer is 1/4<n><n>#### Number of Quarters<n><n>The answer represents how many quarters needed to fill the bottle to its maximum capacity. <n><n>The answer is: 4<n><n>## Instruction: Complete the following multiple-step Inequality.<n><n>## Rationales: 6>6+4<n>1) The 6<sign  represents < or inequality<n>2) The + sign represents the addition of the numbers<n>3) The 4 represents the value<n><n>## Instruction(s): Answer the following multiple-step problem.<n><n>## Rationale: (1.5)<(1.5)+(1.5)/2<n>>1.5>1.5+1.5/2<n>-1.5>

Where is James? Choices:  A: dairy farm B: texas C: building D: michigan E: florida<n><n>### Response:		James has a family farm in texas<n><n>### Rationales: It did say only one of the answers was correct, so it wouldn't make much sense if he was in Florida. The only way it would make sense to be in Florida would be if a family farm existed in FL. It also doesn't say anything about the family farm "being" in Texas but I assumed it was the best steakhouse was in Texas.<n><n>### Input - multiple choice:  If you had $3.5 billion, how many months would it take you to spend $1 billion? Choices I: three years<n>II: three months<n>III: a short amount of time<n><n>### Response - multiple choice: answer choices are I and II<n><n>### Rationale for answer choice I: <n>The first sentence said you would have $3.5 billion which means the question is asking how long the 3.5 billion would last. Given this information, it would take 3.5 billion / 1 billion = 3.5 years to spend $1 billion.<n><n>### RATIONALES FOR ANSWER CHOICE II:<n>The sentence "If you had $3.6 billion..." contradicts the information in the first sentence which said that you had $3.4 billion, so you don't have $3.6 billion. You can't be asked how long $3.6 billion would last given the fact that you already said you had $3.1 billion and $3.1 billion is not $3.6 billion, so it doesn't make sense why the question is saying you had 3.6 billion. Additionally, in the first sentence they state that you had $370 million and it doesn't make logical sense for you to have $3.6 with this much of a change so your current earnings are not taken into consideration.<n><n>### Inspired By<n>https://www.sentry.io/coding-test-interview-questions-and-exercises/?ref=gtr
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Utensils are used during what evening activity? Choices:  A: backpack B: closet C: drawer D: dinner E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### <n>### D: cupboard<n><n>***<n><n>### Input for demo:Adam, Bill, and Chris go to the park.  The entrance fee is $10 per person and $8 per dog.  They each have a dog.  How much does it cost in total to get everyone on the trip into the park?<n><n>### Solution:<n>The cost for Adam to enter the park is 10 + 8 = <<10+8=18>>18.<n><n>The cost for Bill to enter the park is also 10 + 4 = <<10+4=14>>14.<n><n>The cost that Chris pays to enter the park is a third of 10 plus a seventh of 8 = <<1/3*10=<<1/3*12=4>>4.<n>So he pays 1 + 4 = <<(1+4)=3>>3.<n><n>Chris, Adam, and Bill paid 18 + 14 + 3 = <<18+14+3=45>>45.<n><n>Answer: $45<n><n>***<n><n>###### Instruction:  Write a response that accurately answers the question.<n><n>##Input:In a year's time, the number of dollars it cost you to replace a pair of boots that you currently have was 48% more than it cost to replace it the previous year. How many times did you replace those boots in that same year?<n><n>##Response:<n>You replaced the boots 48/100 * 100 times, and you saved money so that means the total was less than 48 times.<n><n>Answer:<n>3.23333<n><n>***<n>
