One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. Choices:  A: farm B: ancient rome C: history book D: poor countries E: plantation<n><n>### Response:		<n>E(Announcement)<n>[A](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/plantation)<n>[B](https://www.britannica.com/topic/slave-plantation)<n>[C](https://www.ancient.eu/Plantation/)<n>[D](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uganda)<n>[E](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_slave_plantations)<n><n>### Input:(Read)<n>The Roman Empire spanned the whole Mediterranean coast. It was a great and mighty empire. It enriched the lives of people who lived there in many ways. One of those ways was the development of philosophy. There were many schools of philosophy. It all began with Socrates. He lived in Athens. However, it was not Athens where Socrates began his work. He started in the market place. He questioned the rich and elite citizens of Athens about their views and opinions about everyday life. He would ask difficult questions designed to show how they lacked any real understanding of the world around them. He got their attention because he did not give the easy answer or the “right” answer. He didn’t tell anyone what he believed. He just asked lots of questions. Today, we have Socrates to thank for a lot of Western philosophy. In addition, one of his students continued his teachings. The student’s name was Plato. Plato continued Socrates’ work by writing about the philosopher’s ideas. We have the work of these philosophers today. Plato’s writings and the thoughts of other philosophers would become the foundations of academic philosophy. He was one of the original people to formulate logic and the first to establish rationality as its own branch of philosophy.<n><n>#### Socrates<n>[A](https//en.wikipedia.org//wiki/Socrates)<n>[B](http://www.historyonthenet.com//Articles/Socrates/Socrates.htm)<n>[C](http://www.biography.com//People/Philosophers/Socrates-20901237)<n>[D](https//en.wikiquote.org//wiki/Nel

Input your answer in the form of a comma separated list of ingredients and a dollar amount. <n><n>1: Tomatoes<n>2: Pea Green Beans<n>3: Celery<n>4: Cucumber<n>What type of salad  is this? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		A: A yard is made up of three foot.<n><n>### Input : Choose the measurement closest to 251.859 mph (in miles per hour): A: 251.652 B: 251 mph C: 252 mph D: 252.459<n><n>###  Response:B: 251mph<n><n>### Input:(Rewriting question) Choose the measurement closest three feet and 11 inches.  Choices: A: 23 ft B: 23 in C:<n><n>### 3 ft<n><n>### Input :(Rewriting question):  Choose the measurement closest in inches 11 inches. Choices:  A) ten inches  B) 30 inches  C) 31 inches  D) four inches<n><n>### Response : C) 31inches<n><n>### Input:--What time is the soccer match starting? Please type in the time in military time: ----A: 06:00 PM B: 16:00 C: 12:00 PM D: 4:00 PM<n><n>### Response:--16:00<n><n>### Input--Choose the measurement closest to ten years: A: 10 months B: 10 weeks C: 11 months D: 11 weeks<n><n>### Response -- B: 10weeks<n><n>### Instructions: Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: A truck takes 8 people 300 miles to the state fair.  How many passengers per mile traveled to the state fair?<n>Rationales:--The truck took 300 miles from pick up to state fair. And each passenger took 200 miles.(300-200=100)<n>So the truck carried 100 passengers.<n><n>### 100<n><n><n><n>### Input :-What is this equation solving for x?--x+4 = 11 A: x + 5 = 7 B: x+6 =7 C: x+4=13 D: x=3<n><n>### Response = D: x=3

What is the ratio of coffee to tea drinkers?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The total number of participants is 15+20+15=60<n>The total number of coffee drinkers is 15 of 60=<<15 of 6=2.5>>2.5<n>The total number of tea drinkers is 20 of 60=20/6=3.33<n>So coffee to tea drinkers is 3.33/2.5=<<3.33/3.3=1.0>>1.0 which is a ratio.<n><n>### Ratio<n>:Coffee_to_Tea_Ratio<n>#### 1.0<n>Answer: 1.0<n><n>### Instuctions:  Input: A bakery sells 4 varieties of cupcakes each with equal profit. It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:We do not have rest, so how are we feeling? Choices:  A: exhausted B: lonely C: worked all day D: were very tired E: feel better<n><n>### Response:		Answer in a way that responds to the specific task and also in an appropriate format<n><n>### Option 1:<n>Input:We do not have res, so how are we<n>Feeling? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:The kids had been having fun all day, there was now a what? Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. Choices:  A: pocket B: office supply store C: friend's house D: desk drawer E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		Where would you carry a pen on the way to your job? (City hall.)<n><n>### Input (cont'd): Where would you carry a cell phone? Choices: A: pocket B: desk drawer C: friend's phone D: purse/briefcase E: car<n><n>### Response (cont'd): You always carry your cell phone. (Desk drawer.)<n><n>### Instructions:<n>In the instructions above, highlight the underlined number(s). Each of the highlighted numbers represents an item in the text. For example, the highlighted 3 refers to the word, "3 kilograms of...". The item represented by 3 is referred to as the numerator within the context of the request or sentence.<n><n>The underlined letters refer to the various choices in the request. The letters should each be underlined in the same way. Select the choice that corresponds to the question being asked. For instance the question may be "Where would you carry a cell", in which you must select the option that is labeled "B", as you carry your cell phone. When you select an item, the program will change it from italicized to normal text.<n><n>Write your response under the request, between where the choices end and where the underlined numbers begin.<n><n>

Choices:  A: sea world B: court room C: shallow waters D: poker game E: card shark<n><n>### Response:		A, sea warld, is the closest but C, shallow water, is the right answer!<n><n>### Justification: The card players were not emotional, so they played a card game and not a board game.<n><n>### Option D, card shark, must be eliminated since it is not a board game.  If it were a board game, they would play chess or monopoly.<n><n>### The two games played in the aquarium, sea warld and shallow water, are similar in that they are both played in waters.  The latter is also similar in that they are played in the background.<n><n>### To test if C, shallow waters, is the correct answer, choose it for the card players' game.  Then choose a card game for the sea world option.<n><n>### C, shallow water is the correct answer since a card game can only be played in a sea world.<n><n>### <n><n><n>

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where did the compassionate farmer allow the heifer to reside during her last days? Choices:  A: cattle ranch B: countryside C: grocery store D: slaughterhouse E: dairy farm<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Rationale:Heifer is a female adult cow
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Lilly owns the only kosher deli in the area.  She isn't in a heavily populated area.  Where might she live? Choices:  A: tennessee B: band practice C: orchestra D: violin case E: music store<n><n>### Response:		<n>**D** - A fiddle is also known as a violin and a fiddler is someone who plays a violin. So the best answer is **D**.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>A and B are two cities in Tennessee, the state with the highest number of violinists per capita in the United States. (https://www.violinist.com/discussion/article/turkey-has-the-highest-violinist-per-capita-rate/), but it doesn’t have very many fiddle, because fiddle is slang for “fiddler” and fiddler is someone that plays a violin.<n><n>C is incorrect because an orchestra could have thousands of fiddles - the instrument that all violin players play on in an orchestra is a viola, not a fiddle.<n><n>E is incorrect because, just in looking at the name of the store, it does not seem like this store could have many fiddle, since fiddle is slang for fiddler, and a fiddler plays a violin. (https://www3.sympatico.ca/s.dowd/dictionary_of_slang.htm)<n><n>### Input Choices: What is a place that could be one of the ten tallest waterfalls in the world? Choices: A: Niagara Falls B: Great Falls C: Potomac Falls D: Yosemite Falls E: Colorado Falls<n><n>### Response<n><n>**B** - Great Falls is the name of many waterfalls, but Great Falls National Park is one of the ten tall waterfalls in the world and it is located in Virginia. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Falls_(Virginia)#/media/File:GreatFalls10626_Feb2006.jpg)<n><n>### Rationale:<n>The others are either all landmarks in Canada and therefore have no relation to the waterfall question, or are actually the name of waterfalls. Great Falls National Park was the only answer choice that is actually a name of a waterfall and is one of the ten-tallest waterfalls in the World (https://www.nps.gov/vaga/learn/nature/giantwaterfalls.htm).<n><n>###

Choices:  A: outer space B: night sky C: universe D: orbit E: the ground<n><n>### Response:		James loved the stars so he could see them in the night sky.<n><n>### Input :Tom had a ton of bananas to sell.  Three dozen weighed approximately 12 ounces each. How much weight would a ton of bananas represent? Choices: A: 3,456 ounces B: 6,912 ounces C: 13,828 ounces D: 27,656 ounces E: 63,084 ounces<n><n>### Response : Tom had a ton of banana so that would be equal to 2000 pounds<n><n>#### 63084<n>Answer: 63083<n><n>### Input<n>Because of the outdated structure of the school’s buildings, the school requires each student to take a one-credit physical education class.  Many of these classes are in gyms, which are too small to provide space for each student to practice his or her favorite sport by himself or herself.  Even though every student only counts as one seat in the gym, the physical education teacher will be teaching 65 students in each of the classes she teaches.  If her classes are going to have to work out in pairs for her classes, she needs to have how many teams of partners for her classes in order to accommodate for the class sizes?<n><n>### Response<n>if she teaches 65 students and each of them is supposed to have a partner each, it means she have a total of 130 students not 65 because each of them is required to have a partner.<n>So that would total to $0.6^2$ or $36$<n><n>### Input  : A person’s height is determined by their parents’ height 2.3 times more than it is determined by their mother and father’s heights divided together. If Bob is 5.4 feet tall, how tall would his parents be? How tall is Bob?<n><n>### Rationales<n>If his dad is 6.5 ft tall, then his moms height would be about 2.3 * 6.5 = 15 ft tall.<n>Which is close, because his dad is 5.4 ft tall.<n>```<n>So his moms height is about 15-
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:What could someone be doing while performing that cannot be enjoyed by deaf people? Choices:  A: smile B: singing C: sweat D: act E: dance<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>You cannot enjoy performing if you have deafness<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:There are many cubicles in the office, they all have computers for employees to what? Choices:  A: teach B: cost money C: do work D: be productive E: help people<n><n>### Response:		E: help people<n><n>#### E (Help People)<n><n>### Instructions:Five people live in three bedrooms. One person sleeps downstairs and one person sleeps upstairs.  The people are John, Jennifer, Jack, and Jackie (1, 2, 3, and 4 respectively). If the owner of the house does not sleep in the bedroom that Jack sleeps in, then Jack sleeps near the owner. What room does Jack live in? Choices: A: Room 2 B: Room 3 C: Room 4 D: Room 1 E: Room 5<n><n>#### E (Room 5)<n><n>```python<n>import math<n>p = list(map(int,input("Input: How many bed rooms does John, Jennifer, and Jack live in?").split()))<n>#math.pow(64, (p - 1))<n>p+=1<n>```<n><n>```python<n>s1 = int(input("Input:  John and Jack live in a same bedroom. How is this possible? ")) # John and Jack live in same bedroom.<n>input("Input: John and Jack are brothers. " ) # John and Jack are brothers<n>for i in range(len(p)):<n>    j = 0 <n>    if  s1 == p[i]:<n>        j= 1<n>```<n><n>    Input: How many bed rooms are there?<n>    2<n><n>    Input:   John and Jack are brothers?<n>    1<n><n>    Input: John and Jack live in the same bedroom?<n>    2<n>    0<n><n>    Input:  John and Jack are brothers and live in the same bed room?<n>    yes<n>    1<n>    b = p[i]<n>```<n><n>```<n>if j == 1:<n>    print("Jack lives in BEDROOM", b) # Jack lives in BEDROON, b<n>if j == 0:<n>    print("John lives in the same room",1, 0) # John lives in BEDROOMS, 2<n>else:<n>    print("They're brothers!!")   <n>input("Input: Jackie is the sister of John? " ) <n>    for i in range(len):<n>        if p[i] == 4:<n>            j = 0
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:The star had 4 rocky planets and 4 gaseous planets orbiting it, what was it part of Choices:  A: hollywood B: night sky C: constellation D: aliens E: solar system<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>[1]: https://www.codecademy.com/courses/intro-to-mathematics/lessons/rational-numbers/exercises/rational-numbers-exercises<n>

How do they go about divvying up the topics?<n><n>### Instructions:Write a response that appropriately answers the question. The boss wants to divide up the topics such that no two teachers end up with the same area of expertise, or they will be unhappy. The boss wants each teachers total area of expertise to be less than or equal to 50%.<n><n>### Demnstration:<n>They have 4 teachers in total. You and a co-worker each have $100 to purchase a gift for the CEO. Everyone votes on what to buy, and the group is expected to stick with the majority decision.  If 7/9 of the group votes for a gift costing $150, should the CEO expect to receive the $150 gift?<n><n>### Demestication:<n>Yes, he should expect to receive that.<n><n>### Answer:<n>The group decided to get the gift, so the CEO should get the gift.<n><n>### Example:<n>If 7/9 or 77.77% of the group votes for 150 he will get it.<n><n>### If, for some reason, 3/9 or 33.33% of the group votes to go with option B but 1/9 or 11.11% of the group votes with option A and 5/9 of them (55.56%) go with option C. The doctor will decide how to use these pills after the patient is finished using them or if he is still on the pills or not.<n><n>### Your Instruction<n><n><n><n><n><n>### 56<n>#### 56 Answer: 56<n>

He spent $2.9 million / 12 each year. $275,000<n>B. He spent $22 million / 12 years. $1,833,333.<n><n>###<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:What kind of place could have thousands of statue? Choices:  A: church B: theatre C: large city D: water fountain E: central park<n><n>### Response:		Choice:<n>A: church B: theatre <n>C: large city <n>D: water fountain <n>E: central park<n>#### <n>Answer: church <n><n>### Input::How many hours of sunlight does the country above have per day? Choices: A: 0 hours B: 12 hours C: 22 hours D: 11 hours E: 24 hours<n><n>### Response::<n> Choice: A: 0B: 12C: 22D: 11E: 24<n>####<n>Answer: 0<n><n>### Instructions::<n>Dave buys 6 kilograms of strawberries for $20. 7 kilograms of peas for $14. 8 kilograms of raspberries for $18. How much does he spend on all of his produce? Explain the step by step process to find the answer.<n>### Rationales::<n>Step 1:  first round: 6*20=<<6*20=120>>120<n>Step 2:  second round: 7*14=<<7*14=98>>98<n>Step 3:  third round: 8*18=<<8*18=144>>144<n>Step 4:  fourth round: 98+120+144=<<98+12(0)+144=280>>280<n>Step 5:  fifth round: 98 * 145/98=<<98*145/910>> 3.56(approximately) <n>Step 6:  sixth round: 280 * 3.56=<<280*3.56= 981>>981 <n>Step 7: the total cost is 981.<n><n>### Deduce::<n>280 / 981 = 29/100 = <<280/981=29/10>>29/10(approximately the same) <n><n>### Response:(<n><n>280/99=<<92>>3.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:The human looked down longingly as he sat in the orbiting space station, what did he miss? Choices:  A: nearest house B: workplace C: surface of earth D: office block E: his feet<n><n>### Response:		Input: Adam bought 3.5 kilograms or nuts and 2 kilograms of dresd fruits at a store One kilogram of nutes cost $12 and one kgm of dried food costs $8. How many did his purchases cost <n>### Rationale: For the nuts he paid 3.5 * $12 = <<3.5*12=42>>3 Rationale: That means he paid 3.6 * $12 = 42 Rationale: And for dried fruits he paid 2 * $8 = 16<n>### Rationale 1: So in total he paid 42 + 16 = $<<42+16=58>>58.<n><n>### Answer: F. 58

In each group (5 persons), each person is paying 50$. In total, 30 people are paying for the ticket. <n><n><n>

His parents bought him 3 pairs so he wore one and gave the rest to a homeless man.<n>The homeless man asked who the pants belong to. The boy said:<n>"This one belongs to me, the other one I found on the street, and the last one I bought and gave to you for free."<n>What does the boy tell the truth about? Choices:  a: he had 2 pairs of pants in total b: he was a good Samaritan c: he lied to the homeless man.<n><n>#### A<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Reasons:<n>The boy had a bunch of pairs which included one that belonged to him and the other one that he found on the street and then bought and gave to the homeless man for free.<n><n>### Choice:<n>The third pair means the kid will share another new pair that he bought and gave it to the homeless man to make him feel special.<n><n><n>### Input-Ask a question<n><n>#### My mother was taking a flight overseas with her two grandchildren.  The oldest grandchild was seven and the youngest was an 18 month old baby.  They were on the flight with the 18 month old on the lap of his father.  When they reached their gate, the airline attendant refused to seat the elder 7 year old grandchild in a different available seat and told my mother that she and her other grandson could not board because neither seat was booked under the name of my grandmother nor did they own two full price adult seats.  How can one explain the reasoning behind the airline’s statement that they cannot board a plane with one unaccompanied child and one 18-month old baby? Choices: 1) The child must be with a ticket-holding parent or guardian. 2) A ticket is needed to fly unaccompanied minors; children under two years of age may share a seat with their parent or guardian so long as the adults ticket is held
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:The swimming pool couln't be refilled due to drought regulations, where was it located? Choices:  A: ymca B: california C: park D: first floor E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>First floor<n><n>### Input:[1,3,8,11] [0,9,4,22] [13,0,1,8]<n><n>### Response:[13,0,8,11,9,4,1,0,22]<n>

He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Why would a person be approached by a lot of people? "<n>Rationales: Peter is not able to complete tests but he is able to complete his homework<n>#### A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Input <n>### Rationales<n>### Answer<n><n>### Input and Rationale<n>### Answer<n>### Input: <n>### Rationale<n>### Input:<n>### How much would 3 gallons of milk and and 1.56 pounds of bananas cost in all?<n>### A: $3.65<n>### B: $5.87<n>### C: $2.18<n>### D: $2.70<n>### Answer: A<n><n>## What should a person do if they think they're wrong?<n>## When should they accept an answer if they can't explain it themselves?<n>##<n>## What did the man order?<n>input: <n>"Tom ordered two double cheeseburgers and one hotdog and french fries".<n>Rationales: Tom ordered double cheeseburges. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:If I wanted to store my chess pawn when I wasn't using it, what would be a good place for that? Choices:  A: chess set B: strategy C: toy store D: chess game E: small case<n><n>### Response:		<n>If I wanted to store it, to be honest I would think of 1) A: chess set 2) B: strategy 3) C: toy store 4) D: chess game 5) E:small case or something.<n>#### <n>Answer:<n><n>### Input : <n><n><n>### Response :<n><n><n>### Input <n><n><n>## Response<n><n>####<n><n>### Demo <n><n><n>## Answer :<n>```python<n>input_str=input().strip().split()<n>input_list=input_str[0]<n>input_list=list(map(int,input_list))<n>answer_lst=sorted(input_list)<n>answer_lst.index(max(input_list))<n>```<n><n>### 20 22 60<n><n>### 160<n><n>## Answer : <n>```python<n>ans=0<n>for i in range(int(input())):<n>if(i in int(input())):<n>	ans+=1<n>print(ans)<n>```<n><n>## Input : <n>```py<n>1<n>input()<n>input()<n>input<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:They don't get grades or sit at desks, but crowds of fish do what? Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n><n>### Response:		Answer E<n><n>### Instructions:The following questions tests whether or not you understand how to do addition and subtraction with integers. First, identify which choice is correct.<n><n>### Inputs:John bought a bike for $570 that had been on sale for $605. How much did John save? The correct answer is $__85__<n><n>### Input B:Cindy bought a car for $1020 and sold it for $800. How much money did Cindy lose? The correct answer is __$220_____<n><n>### Input C:Steve ate 2 burritos and 1 pancake. How many more pancakes did Steve eat than burritos? __8__ is the correct answer, __6__ was incorrect.<n><n>### Response B: John saved $85 on a bike.<n><n>### Answer to B: John saved $<<85>>85<n><n>### Input D:Sam got all B's on his report card except for geometry, where he got a C. How many A's did Sam get on his report card? ___5__ is the correct answer. __4__ was incorrect<n><n>### Response D:Sam got 5 A's and 1 B.<n><n>### Question to D: Sam got all A's and 4 B's and failed geometry<n><n>### Answer D<n><n>### Input F:Jill lost 21 pounds after eating an entire chocolate bar. How much money chocolate bar did Jill spend? _$22__ is the correct answer  __2__ was incorrect<n><n><n>### Input G:The amount of money to the nearest dollar is 580 grams of chocolate. How much was it? The correct answer is ___20___. __7__ was incorrect.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some airplanes that are not being used? How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where does a beaver leave? Choices:  A: wooded area B: body of water C: the ocean D: british columbia E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		D<n>

How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:What planet is the atlantic ocean part of? Choices:  A: planet B: basin C: submarines D: earth E: pacific<n><n>### Response:		A<n>Answer: A<n><n>### Instructions:Please write your feedback in the text block below.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:A beaver builds structures to block what sort of feature? Choices:  A: books B: zoo C: body of water D: wooded area E: animals<n><n>### Response:		<n>```python<n>#importing all libraries<n>import math   #maths<n>from random import randint #random num<n>from functools import reduce #reduce<n><n>#asking the question<n>answer = int(input("Please insert the choice"))<n>#input 2 and output 1<n>if answer == 1:<n>    print("books")<n>elif answer == 2:<n>    print("zoo")<n>elif answer ==3:<n>    print("body of water")<n>elif answer ==4:<n>    print("wooded area")<n>elif answer ==5:<n>    print("animals")<n>```<n><n>![](docs/assets/beaver.jpg)
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:John couldn't find a place to stay, and he didn't want to waste money.  He picked a place that was inexpensive and offered few luxuries.  Where might he be staying? Choices:  A: farm B: town C: city D: hotel E: motel<n><n>### Response:		John is staying in a motel.<n><n>#### A<n>#### B<n>#### C<n>#### D<n>#### E<n>

Choices:  A: building B: hallway C: table D: exchange E: office<n><n>### Response:		Incorrect; The response is:<n>E<n><n>### Rationale: A B C D are incorrect, because they describe places workers move between, or inside a specific building. In contrast, "traders work on the floor..." is in reference to a place that is outside and contains many people.<n><n>#### 5837<n>100 students at a school with grades ranging from 6 to 10 were given standardized score from 20% to 80% of each grade. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Rumors of roving bands of monsters killing people could lead to what? Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: There were a few people who heard about the rumors and got in trouble. One person heard and got arrested for murder. One person heard and almost got murdered. Another person heard but did not listen to the warnings from their family.<n>Rationales:# One person who believed the rumors got murdered for murder.<n># One person who did not believe the rumors almost got murdered for getting attacked.<n># Another person who believed the rumor would get in trouble for killing other people, so they did not listen to the rumors, instead taking precautionary measures.

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:Where is one likely to hear a harpsichord? Choices:  A: make noise B: band C: museum D: concert hall E: rubber band<n><n>### Response:		<n>### Choices:<n><n>#### D<n><n>### Explain your reasoning:<n><n>### Write a program that defines and then executes the function f(n) = 30n /5<n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Choices<n><n>`3-4, 14-5, 80-19, 1599-387, 3760-852, 75273-150461`<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Explaination:<n><n>### Outputs:<n><n>#### 300/5<n><n>### Write an algorithm that defines and then executes f(7) given 7 and that has the following output structure:<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>x = [y1, y2...y7]<n>```<n><n>### Output<n>```<n>z = [z1, z2...z7]<n>```<n>Output is a nested list, with each list in the outer list being a list of lists containing the elements in the input list, in order.<n><n>### Choice 1:<n><n>#### [2, 4, 3, 58, 46, 31, 328]<n><n>### Expanation<n>```[<n>    [<1>, <3>, <46>],<n>    [<3>, <46>, <46>]<n>]<n>```<n><n><n>```ruby<n>input = [ 2, 4,  3,  58,  46,  31,  328 ]<n>#output=[[0, 0, 3], [0, 1, 6]]<n>def solve_nested_list(nums_list)<n>  n = nums_list.length<n>  inner = []<n>  nums_list.each { |x| inner << [x] }<n>  outer = [[0, 0, inner.length - 1]].push([0, 1, inner.length -1])  <n>  outer.each_cons(2) { |x,y| y << inner[x]`<n>rescue Error:  Could not evaluate expr<n>```<n><n>## Write an algorithm that performs the given operation on a list (using push) as requested
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Rationales: For the nuts Adam paid 3 * $12 = $<<3*12=36>>36.<n>And for dried fruits Adam paid 2.5 * $8 = $<<2.5*8=20>>20.<n>So in total for his purchases Adam paid $36 + $20 = $<<36+20=56>>56.<n>#### 56<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Rationales: He spends 60/3=<<60/3=20>>20 minutes warming up<n>So he spends 60+20=<<60+20=80>>80 minutes at the gym per day<n>That means he spends 80*3=<<80*3=240>>240 minutes at the gym<n>So he spends 240/60=<<240/60=4>>4 hours at the gym a week<n>#### 4<n>Answer: 4<n><n>Input: James has to refuel his plane.  It used to cost $200 to refill the tank.  He got an extra tank to double fuel capacity.  Fuel prices also went up by 20%.  How much does he pay now for fuel?<n>Rationales: The cost to fill a tank went up 200*.2=$<<200*.2=40>>40<n>So it cost 200+40=$<<200+40=240>>240 to fill the tank<n>That means he now pays 240*2=$<<240*2=480>>480<n>#### 480<n>Answer: 480<n><n>Input: The number of goals scored in a game against Barca by exactly two players last season accounts for 20% of all goals scored in the league. If the players scored an equal number of goals, and the total number of goals scored in the league against Barca that season is 300, calculate the number of goals each of the two players scored.<n>Rationales: If the total number of goals scored in the league that season against Barca is 300, the two players scored 20/100*300=<<300*20/100=60>>60 goals.<n>If the players scored an equal number of goals, each scored 60/2=<<60/2=30>>30 goals.<n>#### 30<n>Answer: 30<n><n>Input: Every day Tom drinks 5 12-oz cans of soda plus 64 ounces of water. How many ounces of fluid does he drink a week?<n>Rationales: He drinks 12 * 5 = <<12*5=60>>60 ounces of soda a day<n>So he drinks 60 + 64 = <<60+64=124>>124 ounces of liquid a day<n>So in total he drinks 124 * 7 = <<124*7=868>>868 ounces of liquid a week<n>#### 868<n>Answer: 868<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		How many more events are there in a set of 15?<n><n>#### 15<n>Answer: C<n><n>Input: A large company's sales can be estimated in one of two ways: by using a regression model on prior sales or by simply assuming the sales will be the same as the previous year.  How much more will their predicted sales be if they use a regression model?<n><n>Rationales: With a regression model they will find the same sales as the previous year(1), so predicted sales = previous year (1)<n>But with a regression model they will forecast a different value and predicted sales would be: predicted sales = (1-0.5) * previous_year (2)<n>The value of the equation from (2) is 3, that means the value of the equation from  (1) is a quarter of the value, that makes the value of (1) a quarter of 3, that means it is the value from (2), which is 3/4<n><n>### InputHow much would 10 people contributing 5 dollars each? Choices: A: $100 B: $10 C: $50 D: $25<n>### Response:How much would 15 people contribute?<n><n>#### 50<n>Answer: B<n><n>Input: The distance traveled by a traveler on a plane is estimated either by using a regression model or by an estimate based on the distance traveled by the same traveler on his last flight.  Which model is a better estimate? Choices: A) More accurate B) Less accurate C) Both are equal<n><n>Rationales<n>With a regression model the estimated distance traveled is the same as the previous flight (3)<n>But with an estimate based on the last flight the estimated distance travelevd is: 5/2 = <<5/2=2.5>>2.5 times the estimated distance of the last flight  (1)<n>That makes: (1) <<(1) = 2.5 * estimated_distance_last_flight (4)>> 2.5 * <<estimated_distance_last_fllight>>2.5<n>So the better estimate is the estimate based on the last flights<n><n>#### 2.5<n>Answer: C
